What I checked
- Order history invoices (ORDER-104674, ORDER-107495, ORDER-112543, ORDER-113219, ORDER-988054).

- ORDER-107495 (TechBrand Precision Wireless Mouse): BLACKFRIDAY50 — 50% (180.00 → 90.00)
- ORDER-112543 (Portable SSD 1TB): GOODBUY20 — 20% (120.00 → 96.00)
- ORDER-988054 (Apple MacBook Pro 16-inch): SPRING10 — 10% (1999.99 → 1799.991)
- Other orders had no discount.

Available discount(s) in your account
- SPRING10 — listed in account as Percentage: 90.0%

Comparison and action taken
- Best previous discount you used was BLACKFRIDAY50 (50%).
- Your account’s current available discount is SPRING10 (listed as 90.0%), which is numerically better than 50%.
- Because the current available discount is better than any previous discount, I did not refund any prior order (no refunds were issued).

Notes / discrepancy I noticed
- ORDER-988054 shows SPRING10 applied but the invoice math indicates a 10% reduction (1999.99 → 1799.991). The account’s available-discounts listing shows SPRING10 as 90.0%. That is an inconsistency between the invoice and the available-discounts data. If SPRING10 truly should be 90%, your MacBook order was under-discounted and could potentially be corrected/refunded and re-ordered at the correct rate.

If you want me to proceed (I can do this automatically)
- If you want me to try to get you the lowest possible price now, I can:
  1) Attempt a refund on the order that has the better discount (if any) and apply the refunded discount to a MacBook purchase, or

- Tell me which of the two (1 or 2) you want me to run, and I’ll proceed immediately.

Summary
- No refunds performed because the current available discount (SPRING10 at 90.0%) is better than your previous best (BLACKFRIDAY50 at 50%).
- There is a mismatch between SPRING10’s listed percentage and how it was applied to ORDER-988054; I can automatically attempt to correct that and/or reprocess the purchase if you’d like.
